ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class provided a broad yet thorough overview of Maya prehistory.
I learned about the Maya peoples + some about the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Olmec
I learned about the ancient Maya. Topics included society, religion and political structure. We learned about archeological developments and controversies surrounding schools of thought.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The instructor was the biggest strength of the course, Professor Chinchilla is extremely knowledgeable and is very responsive to emails.

It was an excellent course. Well directed, with detailed attention to many eras and aspects of a very complex culture. A thorough survey of culture, geography, and archaeological history of the ancient Maya, with attention to relevance to the modern Maya.

The strengths of this course is Professor Chinchilla who is an expert in the field and is able to present various points of views and the teaching staff. A weakness would be that sometimes the course felt disorganized.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: One successful practice was calling on people by name to answer questions. It can be very awkward to answer questions on zoom because you often begin by cutting someone else off, so when Professor Chinchilla called on people specifically it helped cut down on this problem.
I thought the live leminar format was as good as virtual learning can be. I enjoyed going to this class because it was a good balance of lecturing and discussion.
The readings and discussion over the readings were good practice and I think something that could have been improved was the structure of class discussion over the lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone interested in learning about the Maya, although archaeology was emphasized less than history, so another class may be better for people interested in learning about archaeology specifically.
Prof Chinchilla is an AMAZING professor -- he knows the material really well and is so fun in class.
Yes, this is an excellent course to take if you are interested in anthropology and archeology, Professor Chinchilla is an expert who does his best to keep the class engaging.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
